Author: Jan EkstrÃ¸m, jan.ekstrom@dk.ibm.com, @ekstrom


# Pre-requisites

** This flow is for ingesting CSV data into Db2 **

This Node-RED flow needs to run on a local installation as it requires access to a file system for CSV file ingestion.

Node-RED library dependencies:
- node-red-dashboard
- node-red-contrib-ui-upload
- node-red-contrib-chunks-to-lines
- node-red-nodes-cf-sqldb-dashdb


# Instructions

STEP 1) 
Edit the data in the first section of the "Set Flow data" function node.
The data will be stored in flow variables and used in the other function nodes when activated, so it should automaticaly be used if the data is correct.

TIP: You might need to contact the MAS Admin to get the Monitor API Key and Token.

IMPORTANT: The order and names of the metrics MUST be the same as in the CSV file.
   
STEP 2) 
Open the GUI in http://localhost:1880/ui
This will show you the status of the metric table you have defined in step 1. If the table has not yet been created (look at the status field in the UI) then simply click on the Create Table inject node in this flow.

STEP 3) 
Edit the credentials in the Db2 (dashdb) node.
Edit the line object and data ingestion line so that you have a successfull ingestion into the database table.

TIP: You might need to contact the MAS Admin to get the credentials to the IoT DB2 Warehouse database.

TIP: You can use DBeaver to verify that the data has indeed been ingested.

STEP 4)
Once step 3 is working, then copy the content from the "Format SQL" node in step 3 to the "Format SQL" node in step 5. It is only the part between:
// BEGIN: THIS SECTION CAN BE COPIED TO STEP 5 "Format SQL" NODE, ONCE IT WORKS.
:
// END

STEP 5)
Edit the credentials in the Db2 (dashdb) node.
Open the GUI in http://localhost:1880/ui if not already done.
You should now see that the status indicate the table exist.

Press the Choose file button and select your csv file - then click on. the play button.

NOTE: The line count is including the first row with the header information.

TIP: It is always a good idea to try with a csv file with a few rows (5-10) before taking the big file(s).

TIP: You might change the delimeter in the "csv" node, to match the delimeter in your CSV file(s).

NOTE: The uploadSql and the chunks-to-lines nodes makes it possible to handle rather large data sets as they make sure the data set is handled in smaller chunks to avoid memory issues - but at the same time ingest 2048 rows into the database at the time (it seems to be a good number from a performance and error avoidance perspective).
